_link.title: I can describe how the composition of fatty acids affects membrane fluidity

toLevel2.question: What type of bond is found between carbon atoms in a saturated fatty acid tail?

options.text: Only single bonds
Only double bonds
options.explanation: Double bonds are a feature of unsaturated fatty acids, not saturated ones.

options.text: Triple bonds
options.explanation: Triple bonds do not occur in fatty acid tails found in cell membranes.

options.text: Ionic bonds
options.explanation: Ionic bonds form between ions, not within fatty acid carbon chains.

toLevel2.question: What structural feature do unsaturated fatty acid tails have that saturated tails do not?

options.text: Kinks caused by double bonds
Straight carbon chains
options.explanation: Straight chains are a feature of saturated fatty acids, not unsaturated ones.

options.text: Longer carbon chains
options.explanation: Chain length is independent of saturation; the key difference is the presence of double bonds.

options.text: Phosphate head groups
options.explanation: Phosphate head groups are part of the phospholipid head, not the fatty acid tail.

toLevel2.question: Which type of fatty acid tail packs tightly together in a membrane?

options.text: Saturated fatty acids
Unsaturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids have kinks that prevent tight packing.

options.text: Polyunsaturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Polyunsaturated fatty acids have multiple kinks, making packing even less tight.

options.text: Branched fatty acids
options.explanation: Branched fatty acids are not the standard category discussed in membrane fluidity.

toLevel2.question: What happens to membrane fluidity when the proportion of unsaturated fatty acids increases?

options.text: Fluidity increases
Fluidity decreases
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids increase fluidity because their kinks prevent tight packing.

options.text: Fluidity stays the same
options.explanation: Changing the proportion of unsaturated fatty acids does alter membrane fluidity.

options.text: The membrane dissolves
options.explanation: Increasing unsaturated fatty acids changes fluidity but does not dissolve the membrane.

toLevel2.question: Why do saturated fatty acid tails reduce membrane fluidity?

options.text: They pack tightly together
They create kinks in the tail
options.explanation: Kinks are caused by double bonds in unsaturated fatty acids, not saturated ones.

options.text: They repel each other
options.explanation: Saturated tails do not repel each other; they pack closely due to their straight shape.

options.text: They are shorter than other tails
options.explanation: Saturated tails are not necessarily shorter; their straight shape is what allows tight packing.

toLevel2.statement: Unsaturated fatty acid tails contain at least one double bond between carbon atoms.
toLevel2.explanation: By definition, unsaturated fatty acids have one or more double bonds in their carbon chain.

toLevel2.statement: A membrane rich in saturated fatty acids is more fluid than one rich in unsaturated fatty acids.
toLevel2.explanation: Saturated fatty acids pack tightly and reduce fluidity, so a membrane rich in them is less fluid.

toLevel2.sentence: Saturated fatty acid tails have only {{blank:1}} bonds and pack {{blank:2}} together.
Double bonds in unsaturated fatty acids create {{blank:1}} in the tail, which {{blank:2}} membrane fluidity.
A membrane with more {{blank:1}} fatty acids will be more fluid because the tails cannot pack {{blank:2}}.

toLevel3.question: How does the presence of double bonds in fatty acid tails affect the arrangement of phospholipids?

options.text: It prevents phospholipids from packing closely together
It causes phospholipids to stack in rigid layers
options.explanation: Double bonds create kinks that disrupt regular stacking, not promote it.

options.text: It removes the phospholipid head groups
options.explanation: Double bonds in fatty acid tails do not affect the hydrophilic head groups.

options.text: It breaks the phospholipid bilayer apart
options.explanation: Double bonds change fluidity but do not break the bilayer structure.

toLevel3.question: Why does a membrane with mostly saturated fatty acids have reduced fluidity compared to one with unsaturated fatty acids?

options.text: Straight saturated tails pack closely, restricting movement
Saturated tails are shorter and create gaps
options.explanation: Tight packing of straight tails restricts movement; gaps would increase fluidity.

options.text: Saturated tails repel each other more strongly
options.explanation: Saturated tails actually attract each other through van der Waals forces when closely packed.

options.text: Saturated tails dissolve more easily in water
options.explanation: Fatty acid tails are hydrophobic and do not dissolve easily in water regardless of saturation.

toLevel3.question: What is the relationship between fatty acid composition and membrane function?

options.text: Fatty acid composition controls fluidity, which affects how substances move through the membrane
Fatty acid composition determines the colour of the membrane
options.explanation: Fatty acid composition affects physical properties like fluidity, not the colour of the membrane.

options.text: Fatty acid composition has no effect on membrane properties
options.explanation: The ratio of saturated to unsaturated fatty acids directly influences membrane fluidity.

options.text: Fatty acid composition only affects the outside of the membrane
options.explanation: Fatty acid tails make up both layers of the bilayer and affect the entire membrane.

toLevel3.question: A student says that kinks in fatty acid tails make the membrane more rigid. Is this correct?

options.text: No, kinks prevent tight packing and increase fluidity
Yes, kinks lock the tails into a fixed position
options.explanation: Kinks create space between tails, allowing more movement rather than locking them.

options.text: Yes, kinks make the tails shorter and stiffer
options.explanation: Kinks bend the tails but do not make them shorter or stiffer.

options.text: No, kinks dissolve the membrane entirely
options.explanation: Kinks change fluidity but do not dissolve the membrane.

toLevel3.question: Which description best explains why unsaturated fatty acids increase membrane fluidity?

options.text: Their kinked tails create space between phospholipids, allowing more movement
Their straight tails slide past each other smoothly
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids have kinked tails, not straight ones; straight tails belong to saturated fatty acids.

options.text: Their tails bond covalently with neighbouring phospholipids
options.explanation: Phospholipids in the membrane interact through weak forces, not covalent bonds between tails.

options.text: Their head groups become hydrophobic and fluid
options.explanation: The hydrophilic head groups are not affected by double bonds in the tails.

toLevel3.question: How does the concept of saturated versus unsaturated fatty acids connect structure to function at the molecular level?

options.text: The shape of the tail determines packing, which controls how well the membrane functions
The length of the tail determines the membrane's colour
options.explanation: Tail length does not affect colour; structure-function relates to packing and fluidity.

options.text: The number of head groups determines fluidity
options.explanation: Fluidity depends on fatty acid tail composition, not the number of head groups.

options.text: The type of fatty acid has no connection to membrane function
options.explanation: Fatty acid composition directly affects fluidity, which is central to membrane function.

toLevel3.statement: Kinks in unsaturated fatty acid tails create more space between phospholipids, which is why the membrane becomes more fluid.
toLevel3.explanation: The kinks prevent tight packing, creating gaps that allow phospholipids to move more freely.

toLevel3.sentence: Saturated fatty acid tails are {{blank:1}} in shape, which allows them to pack {{blank:2}}, reducing the overall fluidity of the membrane.
The {{blank:1}} in unsaturated fatty acid tails prevent tight packing, which means the phospholipids can {{blank:2}} more freely within the bilayer.
Membrane fluidity is important because it affects how easily {{blank:1}} can move through the membrane, connecting molecular {{blank:2}} to cell function.

toLevel4.question: A biologist analyses two membranes: Membrane A has 80% saturated fatty acids, and Membrane B has 80% unsaturated fatty acids. Which membrane would allow substances to pass through more easily?

options.text: Membrane B, because unsaturated tails increase fluidity
Membrane A, because saturated tails increase fluidity
options.explanation: Saturated tails pack tightly and reduce fluidity, making the membrane less permeable.

options.text: Both membranes would be equally permeable
options.explanation: The different fatty acid compositions result in different levels of fluidity and permeability.

options.text: Neither membrane would allow any substances through
options.explanation: All plasma membranes allow some substances to pass through; fluidity affects the ease of transport.

toLevel4.question: An organism living in cold water has membranes with a high proportion of unsaturated fatty acids. How does this help the organism?

options.text: It keeps the membrane fluid enough to function at low temperatures
It makes the membrane rigid to protect against cold
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids increase fluidity rather than rigidity.

options.text: It removes cholesterol from the membrane
options.explanation: The proportion of unsaturated fatty acids does not remove cholesterol.

options.text: It prevents the organism from freezing solid
options.explanation: Membrane fluidity helps cell function at low temperatures but does not prevent the organism from freezing.

toLevel4.question: A researcher replaces most of the unsaturated fatty acids in a cell membrane with saturated fatty acids. What change would you predict?

options.text: The membrane would become less fluid and more rigid
The membrane would become more fluid and flexible
options.explanation: Saturated fatty acids reduce fluidity due to tighter packing.

options.text: The membrane would dissolve into the cytoplasm
options.explanation: Replacing fatty acid types changes fluidity but does not dissolve the membrane.

options.text: The membrane would develop pores and leak
options.explanation: Increased saturation reduces fluidity but does not create pores in the membrane.

toLevel4.question: A student models a phospholipid bilayer using straight sticks for saturated tails and bent sticks for unsaturated tails. If they increase the number of bent sticks, what should they observe?

options.text: More gaps between the sticks, representing increased fluidity
Tighter packing of all sticks together
options.explanation: Bent sticks cannot pack as tightly as straight sticks, so gaps would form.

options.text: The sticks would all become the same length
options.explanation: Changing shape does not affect length; the model shows packing differences.

options.text: The model would collapse into a single layer
options.explanation: The bilayer structure is maintained regardless of the mix of tail types.

toLevel4.question: Organism X lives in a hot spring and has membranes rich in saturated fatty acids. How does this fatty acid composition help at high temperatures?

options.text: Saturated tails pack tightly, preventing the membrane from becoming too fluid in the heat
Saturated tails create kinks that stabilise the membrane
options.explanation: Kinks are a feature of unsaturated fatty acids, not saturated ones.

options.text: Saturated tails absorb heat energy from the environment
options.explanation: Fatty acid tails do not absorb environmental heat to protect the membrane.

options.text: Saturated tails dissolve more slowly at high temperatures
options.explanation: The benefit of saturated tails is tight packing, not resistance to dissolving.

toLevel4.question: A cell membrane is analysed and found to have very low fluidity. Which fatty acid composition is most likely present?

options.text: A high proportion of saturated fatty acids
A high proportion of unsaturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids increase fluidity, so a high proportion would produce high fluidity.

options.text: Equal proportions of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Equal proportions would give moderate fluidity, not very low fluidity.

options.text: No fatty acids present at all
options.explanation: Phospholipid membranes always contain fatty acid tails.

toLevel4.question: During an experiment, a drug is added that converts double bonds in fatty acid tails to single bonds. What effect would this have on the membrane?

options.text: The membrane would become less fluid as kinks are removed
The membrane would become more fluid and permeable
options.explanation: Converting double bonds to single bonds removes kinks, reducing fluidity.

options.text: The membrane would not change at all
options.explanation: Removing double bonds changes tail shape and therefore fluidity.

options.text: The phospholipid heads would become hydrophobic
options.explanation: Changes to fatty acid tails do not alter the chemical nature of the head groups.

toLevel4.sentence: An organism in a cold environment would benefit from having more {{blank:1}} fatty acids in its membranes to maintain {{blank:2}} at low temperatures.
If a researcher increases the proportion of {{blank:1}} fatty acids in a membrane, the phospholipids will pack more {{blank:2}} and the membrane will become less fluid.
In a hot environment, membranes with more {{blank:1}} fatty acids are advantageous because tight packing prevents the membrane from becoming too {{blank:2}}.

toLevel5.question: A student claims that adding more unsaturated fatty acids to a membrane always improves cell function. Evaluate this claim.

options.text: The claim is incorrect because too much fluidity can compromise membrane integrity
The claim is correct because more fluidity is always beneficial for cells
options.explanation: Excessive fluidity can make the membrane too permeable and unstable.

options.text: The claim is correct because unsaturated fatty acids also strengthen the membrane
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids increase fluidity but do not strengthen the membrane structure.

options.text: The claim is incorrect because unsaturated fatty acids have no effect on fluidity
options.explanation: Unsaturated fatty acids do increase fluidity; the issue is that too much fluidity is harmful.

toLevel5.question: Two species of bacteria are found in different environments: Species A in Arctic ice and Species B in a tropical river. Which fatty acid composition would you expect in each species?

options.text: Species A has more unsaturated fatty acids; Species B has more saturated fatty acids
Species A has more saturated fatty acids; Species B has more unsaturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Cold environments require more unsaturated fatty acids to maintain fluidity, not saturated ones.

options.text: Both species would have identical fatty acid compositions
options.explanation: Different environmental temperatures select for different fatty acid compositions.

options.text: Neither species would have fatty acids in their membranes
options.explanation: All cell membranes contain phospholipids with fatty acid tails.

toLevel5.question: A membrane sample is found to have intermediate fluidity. What can you infer about its fatty acid composition?

options.text: It likely contains a mix of saturated and unsaturated fatty acids
It contains only saturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Only saturated fatty acids would produce low fluidity, not intermediate.

options.text: It contains only unsaturated fatty acids
options.explanation: Only unsaturated fatty acids would produce high fluidity, not intermediate.

options.text: It contains no phospholipids at all
options.explanation: Without phospholipids there would be no bilayer membrane.

toLevel5.question: A student argues that organisms in extreme heat should have membranes made entirely of saturated fatty acids. What is a limitation of this argument?

options.text: A fully saturated membrane may be too rigid for normal cell processes such as transport
Saturated fatty acids melt at high temperatures so they would be useless
options.explanation: Saturated fatty acids have higher melting points and are more stable at high temperatures.

options.text: There is no limitation; fully saturated membranes work perfectly at all temperatures
options.explanation: Excessive rigidity can impair membrane-dependent processes like transport.

options.text: Saturated fatty acids cannot exist at high temperatures
options.explanation: Saturated fatty acids are stable at high temperatures; the issue is excessive rigidity.

toLevel5.question: Cholesterol is also found in animal cell membranes and helps moderate fluidity. How might cholesterol work alongside fatty acid composition to regulate membrane properties?

options.text: Cholesterol buffers fluidity by reducing it in unsaturated regions and increasing it in saturated regions
Cholesterol replaces all fatty acids and eliminates fluidity entirely
options.explanation: Cholesterol modulates fluidity but does not replace fatty acids.

options.text: Cholesterol only functions in plant cell membranes
options.explanation: Cholesterol is found in animal cell membranes, not typically in plant cell membranes.

options.text: Cholesterol has no interaction with fatty acid tails at all
options.explanation: Cholesterol sits between phospholipid tails and directly affects their packing.

toLevel5.question: An experiment compares three membranes: one with all saturated fatty acids, one with all unsaturated fatty acids, and one with a 50:50 mix. Which would most closely resemble a typical animal cell membrane?

options.text: The 50:50 mix, because real membranes contain both types of fatty acids
The all-saturated membrane, because animal cells need rigid membranes
options.explanation: Animal cell membranes are not fully rigid; they require fluidity for proper function.

options.text: The all-unsaturated membrane, because animal cells need maximum fluidity
options.explanation: Maximum fluidity would compromise membrane stability; real membranes balance both.

options.text: None of them, because animal cells do not contain fatty acids
options.explanation: Animal cell membranes contain phospholipids with both saturated and unsaturated fatty acid tails.

toLevel5.question: A researcher proposes that cells can adjust their fatty acid composition in response to temperature changes. Why would this ability be advantageous?

options.text: It would allow cells to maintain optimal membrane fluidity across different temperatures
It would allow cells to eliminate their membranes when not needed
options.explanation: Cells always require membranes; adjusting composition maintains function, not removal.

options.text: It would make the cells resistant to all environmental stresses
options.explanation: Adjusting fatty acid composition helps with temperature but not all environmental stresses.

options.text: It would prevent the cells from needing cholesterol
options.explanation: Cholesterol serves additional functions beyond what fatty acid adjustment provides.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate the following statement: 'Membrane fluidity is entirely determined by the ratio of saturated to unsaturated fatty acids.'

options.text: This is an oversimplification because cholesterol and temperature also affect fluidity
This is completely correct and no other factors are involved
options.explanation: Cholesterol, temperature, and protein content also influence membrane fluidity.

options.text: This is incorrect because fatty acids do not influence fluidity at all
options.explanation: Fatty acid composition does influence fluidity, but it is not the only factor.

options.text: This is correct for plant cells but not for animal cells
options.explanation: Multiple factors affect fluidity in both plant and animal cells.

toLevel5.sentence: Organisms in cold environments tend to have more {{blank:1}} fatty acids to prevent their membranes from becoming too {{blank:2}}, while organisms in hot environments favour {{blank:3}} fatty acids.
The claim that fluidity depends only on fatty acid composition is an {{blank:1}} because factors such as {{blank:2}} and temperature also play a role in regulating membrane properties.
